NEW YORK -- Abu Hamza al - Masri , an Egyptian - born British cleric , was convicted of 11 terrorism charges on Monday by a federal jury in Manhattan , a verdict likely to strengthen the hand of those who want terror suspects tried in civilian courts , rather than military commissions .

NEW YORK -- Abu Hamza al - Masri , an Egyptian - born British cleric , was convicted of 11 terrorism charges on Monday by a federal jury in Manhattan , a verdict likely to strengthen the hand of those who want terror suspects tried in civilian courts , rather than military commissions .
The monthlong trial marked the second time this year that federal prosecutors in the Manhattan U.S. attorney 's office secured a swift conviction in a high - profile terrorism case .
The monthlong trial marked the second time this year that federal prosecutors in the Manhattan U.S. attorney 's office secured a swift conviction in a high - profile terrorism case .

our office is up to the task , U.S. Attorney Preet Bharara said during a news conference .

Some critics contend military commissions are the more suitable venue for such trials , arguing that many of the rights afforded defendants in civilian courts , the unpredictability of juries and the challenges of handling classified evidence could lead to acquittals .

RelatedSentence: Mr. al - Masri , also known as Mustafa Kamel Mustafa , faces a maximum penalty of life in prison .
As the verdict was read after two days of deliberations , Mr. al - Masri sat silently , wearing a blue jumpsuit .
Outside the courtroom , his attorney Joshua Dratel said he would appeal .
It was not about the evidence but about a visceral reaction to the defendant , Mr. Dratel told reporters .

The defense argued that the government 's case primarily was built on a series of inflammatory statements Mr. al - Masri had made -- such as comparing infidels to cows and pigs , and declaring it acceptable to behead and enslave them -- during his career as a preacher .
The government 's case was bolstered by several cooperating witnesses who testified against Mr. al - Masri in exchange for protection , government stipends and leniency in their own cases .
The government 's case was bolstered by several cooperating witnesses who testified against Mr. al - Masri in exchange for protection , government stipends and leniency in their own cases .

Faxes , voice-mail messages and phone records further supported the prosecution 's claims that Mr. al - Masri played a key role in a 1998 kidnapping of 16 Western tourists in Yemen , an attempt to found a jihadi training camp in Oregon , and the dispatch of recruits to fight with the Taliban and al Qaeda in Afghanistan .

Faxes , voice-mail messages and phone records further supported the prosecution 's claims that Mr. al - Masri played a key role in a 1998 kidnapping of 16 Western tourists in Yemen , an attempt to found a jihadi training camp in Oregon , and the dispatch of recruits to fight with the Taliban and al Qaeda in Afghanistan .
Jury foreman Howard Bailynson said Mr. al - Masri is a skilled orator , but noted that he seemed to have embellished his testimony at times .
